text: this delicious pie pears the sweetness
of candied lemon zest with the soft
floral nosov baked pears and it all gets
wrapped in a flaky tender hot freezing
crust to get started it's nearly 4
pounds of a firm ripe pear
these are Anjou pears and there's about
eight of them and I'm just going to peel
and slice about 3/4 inch wedges will
give you the best texture of pear once
it bakes because pears do get quite soft
in the oven
big chef's knife to quarter them and
then a paring knife will take the core
right out now the core is out I'm gonna
go back to the chef's knife and slice
finish up my pears and then mix with the
rest of the ingredients okay all my
parents are cut so now I'm just gonna
add the rest of the ingredients 1/2 a
cup of sugar 1/4 cup of corn starch this
is the thickness all those juices that
come out of the pears need to be
thickened or it'll be a big mess when
you slice into it then 3/4 teaspoon of
salt 1/4 cup of candied lemon peel this
is really the secret it really adds a
bright tangy note to the pears I always
buy the whole nutmeg and just grate it
just 1/4 teaspoon that's all you need
then some lemon juice I need 2
tablespoons
okay that's it just give it a mix this
is the filling for our pie okay now for
the crust I'm gonna turn the dough as I
go to keep it nice and round and you can
see the little butter clumps and that's
what you want that's how you know you
have a well-made pastry because those
butter clumps will turn into air pockets
that'll create all the flakes on the
dough I'm going to roll it up on the pin
and into my 9-inch pie plate just unroll
it over the top then I'm just going to
use some scissors and then I will put in
all my luscious pears
two tablespoons of butter over the top
this is just going to add some richness
to that pair of filling and I'll do my
top crust roll this right over the top
and then scissors again and now turn the
top crust over the bottom crust this
will create a nice seal I just want to
give it a little bit of a decorative
edge just kind of wave it around a bit
and now with a double crust pie it's
always important to vent the top so that
the crust will be flaky and not soggy
I'm gonna use leaf cutter and make a few
marks right through the top cutting all
the way through the dough now that I
have my leaves I need my stem and I'm
going to use a little cinnamon stick has
a little stem of the pear now some egg
wash I'm just going to paint the whole
top that looks great so this pie is
gonna go into the freezer about thirty
minutes so that the crust really chills
up and then into a 375-degree oven and
it'll take an hour and 15 hour and 30
minutes you want to see the juices
bubbling through those events and then
we know it's done into the freezer here
is our finished beauty it's cooled for
at least four hours I actually like to
cool it overnight and cut it the next
day then I know it's perfectly set let's
cut into it and see how it looks
a delicious pair of pie perfect for this
time of year
